text: This is a download from BBC Learning English.
To find out more, visit our website.
6-Mate English
From BBC Learning English
Welcome to 6 Minute English, the programme where we explore an interesting topic and bring you some useful items vocabulary. I'm Rob.
speaker: Rob

text: and bring you some useful items of vocabulary.
And I'm Neil.
speaker: Neil

text: Now Neil, I know you're a keen swimmer.
speaker: Rob

text: I am. I try to get to the pool once a week and do a few lengths, yes.
speaker: Neil

text: and do a few links, yes.
That's good to hear because swimming is one of the best sports for keeping fit.
It's an aerobic exercise.
Aerobic means a very active type of exercise
that makes your heart and lungs stronger.
The opposite of this is anaerobic.
And for my question today, Neil,
I wonder if you know which of these activities
is an example of anaerobic exercise.
a)    weightlifting
speaker: aerobic

text: b)    kickboxing
speaker: aerobic

text: c)     dancing
speaker: aerobic

text: I don't have a clue but I'll pick my favourite sport – a) weightlifting.
speaker: Neil

text: a)    weightlifting
speaker: Rob

text: Right. Is that really your favourite sport?
Right. Anyway, we'll find out the answer at the end of the programme.
So what about you Rob – do you visit the swimming pool very often?
speaker: Neil

text: Oh, only to use the cafe.
I don't like anything aquatic.
I mean connected to water.
I just don't like getting wet and swimming up and down a pool is just boring.
Well, there are alternative to plain swimming.
There's synchronised swimming.
Right. Synchronised.
That's moving together at the same time or speed as someone else.
Like dancing in water, I suppose.
Hmm. I'm not a good dancer either.
How about the new craze of mermaiding,
which is making a splash at the moment?
In other words, becoming very popular.
The idea originated in America,
but is now popular in the UK and Europe.
OK, well, tell me more.
Let's hear from an expert, Emma Longdon,
who's the founder of Fintofit,
which runs classes teaching the skills of swimming safely,
like a mermaid.
Mermaiding is putting a monofin on your feet,
putting a beautiful tail on and getting in the water,
and swimming like a mermaid.
OK, so I would need to wear a monofin.
The prefix mono means only one or single,
so a single fin, that's like a mermaid's tail.
And then I just get in the water and swim around like a mermaid.
I'm not so sure about that, Neil.
I don't really know how mermaid swim.
There's more to it than that, Rob.
There's more to it than that Rob. It's actually good for your fitness as Emma can explain…
speaker: Neil

text: It gives children's confidence in water's abuse.
It improves their water strength.
It gives you an entire body workout.
It works your cardiovascular system.
It works your legs, your core.
It improves the children's swimming technique,
flexibility, balance, coordination.
You get the reward, you get the social aspect,
and alongside all of that, they're learning vital life skills along the way.
So there are many benefits to mermaiding, Rob,
improving confidence, strength, technique,
and it's good for your cardiovascular system.
Cardiovascular relates to your heart and blood vessels.
Well, I like the sound of the social aspect,
and by that, Emma means being with other people and having fun.
It's an activity that's sociable,
and it teaches life skills, useful skills,
that help you deal with everyday challenges.
Well, that's great for kids, and that's the problem.
What's that?
speaker: Neil

text: Mermaiding is for kids – so I can't get involved – even if I wanted to… can I?
speaker: Rob

text: Can I?
You can, Rob.
You can Rob. According to Emma, it's growing in popularity with adults too – any excuse to live out your fantasies hey!
speaker: Neil

text: Any excuse to live out your fantasies, eh?
There are so many adults that actually kind of want to live out their childhood dreams.
They wanted to be mermaid when they were children,
and they didn't get the opportunity, and now it's here, and now it's available.
And so yes, we do a lot of adult classes as well.
There you go, Rob, living out your childhood dreams.
That's doing things you wanted to do when you were a child.
Like being a mermaid.
Sorry, Neil, that wasn't a dream for me,
although I did dream of swimming like a shark once.
Anyway, mermaiding is a good form of aerobic exercise,
but earlier, I asked you what an example of anaerobic exercises.
Is it a weightlifting, b.
kickboxing, or c. dancing?
I said weightlifting. Was I right?
speaker: Neil

text: You were, Neil, well done.
Any exercise that consists of short exertion,
high-intensity movement is an anaerobic exercise,
such as weightlifting, sprinting, and jumping.
I won't go into scientific detail, but aerobic exercise
is done over a longer period of time and strengthens the heart and lungs,
thereby improving the body's utilization of oxygen.
Thanks for that, Rob. Now, I think we should sprint through our recap of some of the words we've
talked about today, starting with aerobic, which you just explained.
Mermaiding is a good aerobic workout.
Assuming you don't mind dressing up, of course.
Next, we had a quatic, which refers to something connected with water.
Synchronized swimming is an example of an aquatic sport.
You slipped in another of our words there, synchronized,
which means moving together at the same time or speed as someone or something else.
We synchronized our watches so that we all arrived at the same time.
Good idea. You're always late, Neil.
Then we mentioned mono, which means one or single,
and is used as a prefix on words such as monochrome, one color,
or mono-rail, a train running on a single track.
Then we heard the word cardiovascular, a word that relates to the effect on your heart and lungs.

Then we heard the word 'cardiovascular' -  a word that relates to the effect on your heart and lungs. "Experts say those who quit smoking could also quickly reduce their risk of cardiovascular disease."
speaker: cardiovascular' -

text: Finally, we also mentioned social.
Finally, we also mentioned 'social' – this adjective relates to activities that you do with other people and are usually fun. "Now I live in London, I have a great social life."
speaker: social'

text: Now I live in London, I have a great social life.
Well, you never invite me out, Rob.
Sorry.
Anyway, that's it for this edition of 6 Minute English.
Before you rush off to fulfill your dream of being a mermaid,
don't forget to visit our Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and YouTube pages.
And of course, our website.
Yes and that's at bbclearningenglish.com. Bye for now.
speaker: Rob

text: Bye for now.
Goodbye
speaker: Neil

text: 6 Minute English.
From BBC Learning English.
